image.altText: Authorities say the child was carried from the burning building but could not be revived

items.synopsis: Authorities say the child was carried from the burning building but could not be revived.

title.children: Detectives investigate after child dies in Alice Springs house fire

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: Victoria Cross recipient Ben Roberts-Smith's decision to sue the publishers of the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age and The Canberra Times, and three journalists, in the Federal Court over a series of articles published in 2018 backfires.

title.children: Judge delivers devastating blow to Australia's most decorated war veteran

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith dressed in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Justice Anthony Besanko delivers a devastating blow to war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith, who had been suing three newspapers and three journalists for defamation over articles alleging he committed war crimes in Afghanistan. Follow live

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith's major court loss, costs will 'follow inevitably'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Justice Besanko found these allegations of war crimes against Ben Roberts-Smith were proved by the defence argument of substantial truth: That Mr Roberts-Smith murdered an unarmed man by kicking him off a cliff and procuring soldiers under his command to shoot him That Mr Roberts-Smith broke the moral and legal rules of military engagement and is therefore a criminal That he committed murder by pressuring an inexperienced SAS trooper to execute an elderly, unarmed Afghan to "blood the rookie" That he committed murder by machine gunning a man with a prosthetic leg That he was so callous and inhumane that he took the prosthetic leg back to Australia and encouraged other soldiers to use it as a novelty beer drinking vessel That while as deputy commander of an SAS patrol in 2009 he authorised the execution of an unarmed Afghan by a junior trooper
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What war crimes allegations were 'proved'

children.content: Justice Besanko found these allegations of war crimes against Ben Roberts-Smith were proved by the defence argument of substantial truth:
That Mr Roberts-Smith murdered an unarmed man by kicking him off a cliff and procuring soldiers under his command to shoot him
That Mr Roberts-Smith broke the moral and legal rules of military engagement and is therefore a criminal
That he committed murder by pressuring an inexperienced SAS trooper to execute an elderly, unarmed Afghan to "blood the rookie"
That he committed murder by machine gunning a man with a prosthetic leg
That he was so callous and inhumane that he took the prosthetic leg back to Australia and encouraged other soldiers to use it as a novelty beer drinking vessel
That while as deputy commander of an SAS patrol in 2009 he authorised the execution of an unarmed Afghan by a junior trooper

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Chessell, the managing director of publishing at Nine, has welcomed Justice Besanko's decision outside court. He said it confirms the article's reports that Ben Roberts-Smith breached the Geneva Convention and is a "critical step toward justice for families of the murder victims". "And most importantly it is a vindication for the brave soldiers of the SAS who served their country with distinction and then had the courage to speak the truth about what happened in Afghanistan." Mr Chessell said the judgement would have a "lasting impact" on the Australian Defence Force. Journalist Chris Masters said the decision to publish the articles would go down as one of the "great calls" in the news industry. "I’m not standing here as a loser but I don’t think that anybody comes out of a matter like this feeling exultant and triumphant." Nick McKenzie called the decision "justice" and paid tribute to the SAS witnesses who testified against Mr Roberts-Smith. "Australia should be proud of those men."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Today's judgement a 'vindication', Nine boss says

children.content: James Chessell, the managing director of publishing at Nine, has welcomed Justice Besanko's decision outside court.
He said it confirms the article's reports that Ben Roberts-Smith breached the Geneva Convention and is a "critical step toward justice for families of the murder victims".
"And most importantly it is a vindication for the brave soldiers of the SAS who served their country with distinction and then had the courage to speak the truth about what happened in Afghanistan."
Mr Chessell said the judgement would have a "lasting impact" on the Australian Defence Force.

props.alt: A man in a suit speaks with a crowd of people behind him

children.content: James Chessell (centre) speaks outside court
(ABC News)
Journalist Chris Masters said the decision to publish the articles would go down as one of the "great calls" in the news industry.
"I’m not standing here as a loser but I don’t think that anybody comes out of a matter like this feeling exultant and triumphant."
Nick McKenzie called the decision "justice" and paid tribute to the SAS witnesses who testified against Mr Roberts-Smith.
"Australia should be proud of those men."
Chris Masters (left) and Nick McKenzie (right) speak to the media after the decision is handed down.
(ABC News: Harriet Tatham)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We won't receive the written judgement today as Justice Anthony Besanko ordered the Commonwealth be given time make redactions before making it public At the latest, we will receive it by June 5 A smaller section of his decision may or may not ever be revealed, as it was heard in closed court. That is yet to be determined The judge did not find in favour of all the newspapers defence, however, for some of the most serious allegations, including war crimes of murder, he found truth was established This meant the defamation case was dismissed Arthur Moses SC has asked for an extension to appeal for his client Ben Roberts-Smith, while Nicholas Owens SC has asked for 21 days to establish a case for costs, given they were successful in their defence
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What we know so far

children.content: We
won't receive the written judgement today
as Justice Anthony Besanko ordered the Commonwealth be given time make redactions before making it public
At the latest, we will receive it by
June 5
A smaller section of his decision may or may not ever be revealed, as it was heard in closed court. That is yet to be determined
The judge did not find in favour of all the newspapers defence, however, for some of the most
serious allegations,
including war crimes of murder, he found truth was established
This meant the defamation case was dismissed
Arthur Moses SC has asked for an extension to appeal for his client Ben Roberts-Smith, while Nicholas Owens SC has asked for 21 days to establish a
case for costs
, given they were successful in their defence

image.altText: medium clear jellyfish on a wet sand beach.

items.synopsis: Lifesavers warn residents and visitors in the Northern Territory to take precautions against box jellyfish this dry season after a child is stung at a popular Darwin beach.

title.children: Boy stung by box jellyfish at Darwin's Casuarina Beach, prompting dry season warning

image.altText: ABC Broadcaster Charlie King

items.synopsis: Indigenous voices in the Northern Territory say they hope the finalisation of the AFL's investigation into allegations of mistreatment of First Nations players at Hawthorn will not be the end of any action to address culture problems across the code.

title.children: 'We just can't go on': Concerns future racism will be overlooked after Hawthorn probe ends

image.altText: Upwards shot of the BHP building in Perth.

items.synopsis: Mining giant BHP admits it has underpaid almost 30,000 workers, dating back to 2010, and it will cost more than $400 million to make amends.

title.children: 'Deeply sorry': Mining giant BHP admits underpaying almost 30,000 workers

image.altText: a man wearing a fishing shirt holding tools

items.synopsis: A community-led initiative is helping patch up businesses and homes targeted by youth crime. Some victims say they want to leave the regional NT town altogether.

title.children: Break-ins and vandalism take their toll on Katherine residents

image.altText: Head of Wagner Group military company Yevgeny Prigozhin speaks to fighters in a forest area.

items.synopsis: Russia's most powerful mercenary, Yevgeny Prigozhin, asks prosecutors to investigate whether senior Russian defence officials committed any "crime" before or during the war in Ukraine.

title.children: Wagner chief calls for investigation into 'crimes' of top Russian defence officials

image.altText: J MILLA holds an Aboriginal flag, he is on stage

items.synopsis: J-MILLA's poignant and at times confronting lyrics have brought the young Indigenous rapper critical acclaim and a burgeoning social media following. His concert in the small, remote Northern Territory community of Wadeye will be going global.

title.children: Rapper set to make history in tiny Indigenous town

image.altText: Bandt holds his hand in the air as he speaks inside Parliament House.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory government is accused of hiding a report forecasting future emissions to cover up a "very sorry tale" of further increases.

title.children: 'A very sorry tale': Greens leader Adam Bandt accuses NT government of hiding emissions report

image.altText: A young woman leans against the steel border force, looking into the camera.

items.synopsis: Belarus was accused of manufacturing a refugee crisis on the European Union's doorstep two years ago. Now, as close ally Russia wages war nearby, asylum seekers are again at the fence.

title.children: 'I have children who will die if we stay in the forest': Is Putin behind a mysterious migrant crisis?

image.altText: The US Capitol's domed building against a grey sky with a lone US flag flying.

items.synopsis: Mining giant BHP has admitted to underpaying nearly 30,000 employees since 2010, while the ASX has closed higher after the US House of Representatives votes to suspend the debt ceiling.

title.children: ASX finishes higher after US House votes to suspend debt ceiling, easing global economy fears — as it happened

image.altText: A police officer's torso showing a body cam

items.synopsis: A woman's "lonely death" of starvation in the suburbs of an Australian capital city raised "several issues", including with police inaction, a Tasmanian coroner has said.

title.children: Woman starved to death in unit shortly after police welfare check, coroner finds

image.altText: Melbourne OPBD - POI 1

items.synopsis: Police say they are looking for two men who allegedly tricked a vulnerable passer-by into giving them his rent and pension money by pretending to tell his fortune.

title.children: Police launch appeal after vulnerable man conned out of $1,700 in fortune-telling scam

image.altText: Libby Chaplin stands next to a battery recharging station, which has a sticker that says 'Electric Highway Tasmania'

items.synopsis: As Australia passes the milestone of 100,000 electric vehicles on our roads, an environmental downside is looming: huge numbers of batteries that could end up in landfill.

title.children: The triple threat posed by lithium batteries means electric vehicles risk a major downside

image.altText: Black and white cows under a tree

items.synopsis: Cows that eat chocolate don't produce chocolate milk, but it's pretty close. Reject confectionery bars are being eaten by dairy cows in a win for both their food requirements and for reducing landfill.

title.children: These dairy cows crave chocolates and lollies — so it's no surprise their milk is used to make flavoured drinks

image.altText: A drone shot of a town by a lake with snow.

items.synopsis: The NSW Snowy Mountains town has seen the highest rise in median house price of any town or suburb in NSW, according to new data from Proptrack.

title.children: Locals say they've been priced out of Jindabyne as house prices more than double over five years

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: Perhaps it was no accident that Philip Lowe used his Senate Estimates appearance to give the political class some advice about the need to rethink how Australia fights inflation, even if he knew his words would likely fall on deaf ears, writes David Speers.

title.children: At his last stand, Lowe gave some tough advice to the 'political class'. Then the inflation figures landed

image.altText: Phil Egan looks stern standing near a river.

items.synopsis: Indigenous advocates have slammed the AFL's handling of the Hawthorn probe, and urged the league to become a "cultural leader" by addressing alleged mistreatment of First Nations players across the sporting code.

title.children: AFL urged to become 'cultural leader' amid fallout from Hawthorn probe

image.altText: Headshot of Amber-Jade Sanderson standing in front of microphones

items.synopsis: Health Minister Amber-Jade Sanderson, who failed in her bid to replace retiring Premier Mark McGowan, says she is completely behind his successor Roger Cook.

title.children: 'Everyone is behind Roger': WA health minister declares loyalty to incoming premier after failed leadership tilt

image.altText: Kim Cattrall looks over her right shoulder wearing plunging grey strapless dress and stands infront of sex and the city sign.

items.synopsis: She was not part of the show's first season, but Kim Cattrall is stepping back into Samantha Jones's shoes. However, there is a catch.

title.children: And just like that, Kim Cattrall returns as Samantha Jones

image.altText: COVID-19 image

items.synopsis: Scientists still don't know what causes it, how to treat it — or even how to best diagnose it. So how do we know if we have long COVID?

title.children: Scientists say these are the 12 symptoms that reveal when COVID becomes long COVID

image.altText: Noel Payne looking at the camera sitting on a bicycle in a backyard.

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court justice concludes Rebecca Payne suffered more than a decade of "abhorrent" abuse from her husband but there was "no legal justification" for the killing.

title.children: Woman sentenced to 16 years' jail for murdering abusive husband with drug-laced biscuits

image.altText: a close-up of Brahman cattle.

items.synopsis: Australia's northern cattle traders have reacted with anger at the federal government's offer to end the industry's class action.

title.children: Cattle producers slam government's 'insulting' $215 million offer to settle live export dispute

image.altText: A drawing of a house under construction

items.synopsis: What happens when you hear that your building company has gone broke and work on your half-built house comes to a grinding halt?

title.children: Thinking of building a home? Here's what you need to know about the crisis in construction

image.altText: Pharmacy owner Lyn Pilcher standing behind the counter with two of her female employees,  all smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: When this town's residents need to collect the post or the bread, they go to the local pharmacy.

title.children: This town's post office and grocery shop closed, so the pharmacy added mail and bread to the medicines

image.altText: a man standing in a field of cannabis plants

items.synopsis: Hemp advocates hail the much-maligned crop as the billion-dollar saviour to Victoria's ailing timber industry, but politicians are concerned the industry could pave the way to legalising cannabis.

title.children: Is cannabis the new timber? Advocates want industrial hemp to solve Australia’s housing crisis

image.altText: The Russian Embassy site in Yarralumla, Canberra.

items.synopsis: The National Capital Authority has failed to have a lease agreement for a new Russian embassy in Canberra torn up.

title.children: Court rules Russia can have 'quiet enjoyment' of Canberra land that authorities had said to vacate

image.altText: Rosemary Walker solo

items.synopsis: National house prices lifted sharply in May, according to data from CoreLogic. Sydney continues to lead the recovery, with rises across the capital cities, as the number of properties advertised for sale fell further.

title.children: Rosemary paid $35k for a modest Sydney home. When it went to auction 45 years later, she thought she 'was going to faint'

image.altText: An aerial view of rows of seated graduation students with colourful sashes over their black academic robes.

items.synopsis: All HECS-HELP loans will increase by 7.1 per cent today.

title.children: HECS-HELP loans are indexed today. Check how much your loan will increase with our calculator

image.altText: an all-white giant panda treks through the snow

items.synopsis: Believed to be the only known albino panda, its movements were captured on infrared cameras.

title.children: Only known all-white panda spotted for second time in China

image.altText: Danny Masterson wears a face mask looking straight ahead in front of an orange background.

items.synopsis: The actor most well-known for That 70s Show has been found guilty of raping two women in the early 2000s.

title.children: That 70s Show actor Danny Masterson found guilty in rape retrial

image.altText: The launch of the newly developed Chollima-1 rocket carrying the Malligyong-1 satellite at the Sohae Satellite Launching Ground.

items.synopsis: North Korea's Kim Yo Jong — sister of leader Kim Jong Un — says her country will soon put a military spy satellite into orbit as Pyongyang moves to increase its surveillance capabilities.

title.children: North Korea's Kim Yo Jong promises more spy satellite launches as Pyongyang moves to increase surveillance

image.altText: Half of a cut cara cara orange, with pink blush flesh, is held up by a white person's hand.

items.synopsis: New varieties of citrus like cara cara navels and blood oranges are growing in popularity, but farmers say supermarkets need to stock more to grow demand.

title.children: Pink is the new orange with consumers hungry for photo-worthy new citrus varieties

image.altText: A man pumps his fist while standing on a clay tennis court.

items.synopsis: In a clash Nick Kyrgios described as a "popcorn match", Thanasi Kokkinakis brings down Stan Wawrinka at the French Open.

title.children: 'What a match': Kokkinakis brings down a legend to earn biggest win of his career
